arguments.claim: Devolution of Mahantship is always to the senior celibate Chela on death or retirement of incumbent, after installation ceremony

anchor.surface_text: It was his case that under the tenets and the customs of the asthal and Bhagataha sect of Kabirpanthies, the devolution of the office of Mahantship is always from a Guru to the senior celebate Chela ,either, on the death of. the Mahant for the time being or by the said Mahant numberinating. his successor by deed and himself retiring from the Mahantship In either case, after the death or retirement of the Mahant for the time being, the senior chela succeeds to the Mahantship and is duly installed on the Gaddi after the perfomance of Bhandara in an assemblage of Mahants and sadhus of the sect and respectable persons of the locality at which The Chaddar of Mahanthi is bestowed on the new Mahant by the Mahant of Acharya Math Dhanauti in the District of Saran.

A document known as the Surat Hall was prepared regarding the plaintiffs installation.

anchor.surface_text: They pleaded that the custom and usages of the Turki Math relating to devolution of Mahantship was for the Mahant for the time being numberinating a fit and proper person as his successor from amongst his Chelas irrespective of his seniority and the person so numberinated invariably became the Mahant on the demise or retirement of the incumbent Mahant. A ceremony of installation of the new Mahant on the Gaddi and the bestowing of a Chaddar on him were number essential for establishing his title to this office

arguments.claim: From 1899, only senior Chelas succeeded; Mahant nominates senior unless disqualified; nomination subject to approval; ceremony not essential; plaintiff installed

anchor.surface_text: The findings of the trial companyrt were as follows From 1899 onwards only senior Chelas had succeeded their Gurus. According to the custom of the Muth the Mahant had the right to numberinate his successor and the choice rested upon the senior Chela unless he suffered from any disqualification or was found to be unfit for the office. The right of numberination was number absolute but was subject to the approval of others. An installation ceremony was number essential to companyplete the title of the Mahant. Such a ceremony had been performed in the ease of the plaintiff in 1956

arguments.court_reasoning: Reversed on custom (not strict seniority) and installation (not proved)

arguments.claim: No invariable custom of senior Chela; Mahant nominates fit chela considering ability/character; first defendant superior; deeds valid

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected the custom as to succession set up by the plaintiff. It found- Since the time of the founder... The Mahant in office had an undoubted right to numberinate his successor and ordinarily the right of appointment was exercised in favour of the senior Chela but the choice was exercised in favour of a celebrate chela taking into account his all round ability and character... The deeds of numberination and surrender in 1951 and 1952 by the first defendant were valid and binding.

arguments.claim: General law of succession to Mahantship: governed by grant, usage, or custom; claimant must prove affirmatively; Mourasi Mutt allows nomination of fit junior chela; installation not essential

arguments.claim: Documentary evidence shows nomination based on fitness, not always senior (e.g., 1910, 1937, 1947 docs); 1947 doc recites custom of appointing able Brahmachari disciple

anchor.surface_text: The earliest document exhibited in this case is that of 1899... This document goes against the companytention of the plaintiff that by custom the senior Chela was eligible to the office in preference to all others. It recites It has been the practice in the Asthal from the time of my predecessors that the Gadinashin leads a life of Brahmacharya...

arguments.claim: Oral evidence discrepant, mostly interested; qualifications include ability, not just seniority

anchor.surface_text: A fairly large number of witnesses stated that the qualifications for a persons numberination to the Mahantship did number depend only on seniority but on ability to manage, celibacy... Making due allowance for the witnesses who came to support the case of the party examining them, the oral testimony unquestionably leads us to hold that in the matter of numberination of a successor to the Mahantship seniority was number the decisive factor

arguments.claim: Plaintiff's installation in 1956 not proved: Surat Hall not produced earlier, witness denial, self-description as other Mahant, blank paper implausible

arguments.claim: Plaintiff failed to discharge onus to prove custom of succession to senior chela

anchor.surface_text: In the result we hold that the plaintiff was unable to discharge the onus which lay on him to substantiate the custom as to succession pleaded in his plaint. He also failed to establish that he had in fact been installed as the Mahant of the said Math.

holdings.text: The plaintiff was unable to discharge the onus which lay on him to substantiate the custom as to succession pleaded in his plaint.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we hold that the plaintiff was unable to discharge the onus which lay on him to substantiate the custom as to succession pleaded in his plaint.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Documentary evidence (1899-1951 deeds) shows nominations based on fitness not always senior chela; oral evidence confirms ability, character decisive; burden on plaintiff to prove custom affirmatively.

holdings.text: In the matter of nomination of a successor to the Mahantship seniority was not the decisive factor but that ability and efficiency in management coupled with a good moral character and adherence to the religious rites practised at the mutt and a spirit of service to sadhus etc. all entered into consideration in the selection of a successor by a Mahant.

anchor.surface_text: the oral testimony unquestionably leads us to hold that in the matter of nomination of a successor to the Mahantship seniority was not the decisive factor but that ability and efficiency in management coupled with a good moral character

holdings.reasoning_summary: Oral testimony of witnesses and documentary recitals (1910,1937,1947,1951) emphasize fitness, ability over strict seniority; aligns with Mourasi Mutt practice.

holdings.text: A ceremony of installation of the new Mahant on the Gaddi and the bestowing of a Chaddar on him were not essential for establishing his title to this office.

anchor.surface_text: A ceremony of installation of the new Mahant on the Gaddi and the bestowing of a Chaddar on him were not essential for establishing his title to this office in place of the retiring or the deceasing Mahant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent and treatise (Mukherjee p.275) state installation ceremonies not essential; conceded by counsel; trial court found not essential.

holdings.text: The plaintiff failed to establish that he had in fact been installed as the Mahant of the said Math.

anchor.surface_text: He also failed to establish that he had in fact been installed as the Mahant of the said Math.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Surat Hall not produced earlier despite litigation; Acharya Mahant denied signing; plaintiff self-described as Mahant of another math in 1956 petition; blank paper signing implausible.

holdings.text: The deeds of nomination and surrender in 1951 and 1952 by the first defendant were valid and binding.

anchor.surface_text: The deeds of nomination and surrender in 1951 and 1952 by the first defendant were valid and binding.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Valid under Mourasi Mutt custom allowing nomination inter vivos and surrender; supported by evidence of fitness; no violation of proved usage.

holdings.text: Turki was a Mourasi Mutt where the office devolves on chief disciple nominated by incumbent Mahant, who may select junior if more capable.

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly Turki was a Mourasi Mutt... In a Mourasi Mutt the chela or disciple of the last Mohunt succeeds to the office when there are more, chelas than one the eldest generally succeeds, but a junior chela may succeed if he is found more capable and if he is selected by the last Mohunt is his successor

holdings.reasoning_summary: Admitted fact; general law from Privy Council and treatise confirms nomination by incumbent, preference for fit chela over strict seniority.

holdings.text: The party who lays claim to the office of a Mohunt on the strength of any such usage must establish it affirmatively by proper legal evidence.

anchor.surface_text: the party who lays claim to the office of a Mohunt on the strength of any such usage must establish it affirmatively by proper legal evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Settled general law from Privy Council decisions and treatise; applied to facts where plaintiff bears onus.
